title: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Rumination Syndrome
description: Official Rome IV diagnostic criteria for rumination syndrome in adults, a functional gastroduodenal disorder characterized by effortless regurgitation of recently ingested food followed by remastication and reswallowing or expulsion. This validated diagnostic tool distinguishes rumination syndrome from GERD and other gastroesophageal disorders through specific clinical criteria emphasizing effortless regurgitation without retching or nausea.

parameters.name: persistent_recurrent_regurgitation
parameters.description: Persistent or recurrent regurgitation of recently ingested food into the mouth with subsequent spitting or remastication and swallowing for ≥3 months with onset ≥6 months ago
options: yes - Patient experiences persistent or recurrent regurgitation of recently ingested food with remastication and reswallowing or expulsion
no - Patient does not experience the characteristic regurgitation pattern or does not meet temporal criteria

parameters.name: regurgitation_not_preceded_by_retching
parameters.description: Regurgitation is not preceded by retching (effortless regurgitation)
options: yes - Regurgitation occurs effortlessly without preceding retching movements
no - Regurgitation is preceded by retching or forceful abdominal contractions

parameters.name: exclusion_gi_bleeding
parameters.description: Exclusion of signs of gastrointestinal bleeding
options: yes - No evidence of gastrointestinal bleeding (melena, hematemesis, hematochezia)
no - Signs of gastrointestinal bleeding present requiring investigation

parameters.name: exclusion_iron_deficiency_anemia
parameters.description: Exclusion of unexplained iron deficiency anemia
options: yes - No unexplained iron deficiency anemia present
no - Unexplained iron deficiency anemia present requiring evaluation

parameters.name: exclusion_heartburn_reflux
parameters.description: Exclusion of significant heartburn or esophageal reflux symptoms
options: yes - No significant heartburn or esophageal reflux symptoms
no - Significant heartburn or esophageal reflux symptoms present

parameters.name: exclusion_weight_loss
options: yes - No unintentional weight loss (>10% body weight over 6 months)
no - Unintentional weight loss present requiring evaluation

parameters.name: exclusion_abdominal_mass_lymphadenopathy
parameters.description: Exclusion of palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy
options: yes - No palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on examination
no - Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy present

parameters.name: exclusion_dysphagia
options: yes - No dysphagia for solids or liquids

parameters.name: exclusion_persistent_vomiting
options: yes - No persistent vomiting episodes distinct from regurgitation

result.name: rome_iv_rumination_syndrome_diagnosis
result.description: Rome IV diagnostic assessment for rumination syndrome based on fulfillment of all required criteria

ranges.description: Does not meet Rome IV criteria
ranges.interpretation: Patient does not fulfill Rome IV diagnostic criteria for rumination syndrome. One or more essential criteria are not met or exclusion criteria are present. Consider alternative diagnoses including GERD with regurgitation, gastroparesis, eating disorders, or organic gastrointestinal pathology. Further evaluation may be needed including upper endoscopy, gastric emptying studies, and psychological assessment as clinically indicated.

Patient fulfills Rome IV diagnostic criteria for rumination syndrome. Diagnosis is established when all criteria are met including persistent regurgitation of recently ingested food with remastication and reswallowing, effortless regurgitation without retching, and exclusion of organic causes. Treatment focuses on behavioral interventions including diaphragmatic breathing training, habit reversal therapy, and biofeedback. Dietary modifications and psychological support may be beneficial.

references: Stanghellini V, Chan FK, Hasler WL, Malagelada JR, Suzuki H, Tack J, Talley NJ. Gastroduodenal disorders. Gastroenterology. 2016 May;150(6):1380-1392. doi: 10.1053/j.gastro.2016.02.011.

formula: Rome IV Rumination Syndrome Diagnosis = ALL criteria must be met for ≥3 months (onset ≥6 months ago): (1) Persistent regurgitation with remastication/reswallowing + (2) Effortless regurgitation without retching + (3) Exclusion of all alarm symptoms and organic causes (GI bleeding, anemia, heartburn, weight loss, masses, dysphagia, vomiting)
notes: Rome IV diagnostic criteria for functional gastroduodenal disorders
All criteria must be fulfilled for positive diagnosis
Rumination syndrome is characterized by effortless postprandial regurgitation
Regurgitation typically occurs within 30 minutes of eating
Regurgitant contains recognizable food with pleasant taste initially
Process ceases when regurgitated material becomes acidic
Effortless regurgitation usually not preceded by nausea
Distinguished from GERD by absence of heartburn and acid reflux symptoms
Distinguished from gastroparesis by normal gastric emptying
Distinguished from eating disorders by absence of intentional behavior
Often misdiagnosed as refractory GERD or vomiting
Diaphragmatic breathing training is first-line therapy
Habit reversal therapy and biofeedback are effective
Dietary modifications may include smaller, more frequent meals
Prognosis generally good with appropriate behavioral treatment
Nocturnal regurgitation makes diagnosis less likely but does not exclude it
